resources.string: The mission of the Department of Computer Science and Information Systems at SVSU is to provide an outstanding education to its students in accordance with the guidelines of the SVSU mission, to advance scholarship in the key domains of the computing and information systems sciences, and to engage in activities that improve the welfare of society and enhance the reputation of SVSU. \n\nThe department will provide its students with balanced programs which emphasize the knowledge of the core principles of computer science; the skills necessary to use computers to solve real-world problems; experience in implementing solutions with modern computing tools; the communication skills necessary to work effectively in a team; and fostering a high level of faculty/student interaction and mentoring.

The CS and CIS programs share a common foundation. COMM 105A, PHIL 205A (or 210B), and RPW 304 provide a base for communications and professional ethics. CS 105, 146, and 116 comprise a typical first year of CSIS classes, followed by CS 216, CS 245, and CIS 255/355 and 357 in subsequent semesters.

At the 300 and 400 level, the SVSU CS program goes deep into theoretical concepts of data structures, programming languages, and what computers are able to accomplish. CS majors will also gain a deeper understanding of computer architecture, networks, databases, and operating systems. As such, the CS program also requires a more substantial higher math commitment.\n\nBy comparison, the CIS program places greater emphasis on real-world business factors, project management, and system administration. As such, its higher math component is less demanding.
